title: What Survives Saponification? - Soap Ingredient Reality Check
author: Soapmaking Forum Community
overview: Community discussion on what ingredient properties actually survive the saponification process, debunking marketing claims about herbal infusions and extracts in soap

short_answer.reality: Not enough to honestly claim anything medicinal
short_answer.rinse_off_factor: Even if something survived, contact time is nearly nil
short_answer.enjoy_for: Fun, nostalgia, or color where they last

medical_claims_legality.us_law: Claiming medical effects for soap is illegal without rigorous testing
medical_claims_legality.drug_claims: Curing disease, treating acne = drug claims requiring FDA approval
medical_claims_legality.facility_requirements: Expensive testing and facility inspection required
medical_claims_legality.hair_regrowth_claims: Dishonest - no evidence for any herbal/fruit extract
medical_claims_legality.company_tactics: Set up biased tests to get desired marketing results

blueberry_extract.applies_to: Any herbal or fruit extract making drug claims

adding_at_trace.reality: Soap still going through saponification at trace

pine_tar_soap.science: Doesn't do well in science-based studies

hot_process_after_cook.method: Add ingredients AFTER HP cook is complete
hot_process_after_cook.timing: At end of cook, not during
hot_process_after_cook.note: Some success reported by HP soapers

superfat_method.technique: Make HP with 0% superfat in calculator
superfat_method.then: Add oils/butters after cook as the superfat
superfat_method.example: Adding shea butter at end as superfat
superfat_method.calculation: Superfat weight = percent of total oils

late_addition.principle: Add extras at last possible moment before solidification
late_addition.leverages: Superfat percentage that won't be saponified

high_ph_issue.problem: Soap has high pH that some hair doesn't tolerate
high_ph_issue.irony: Soap shampoo bars can CAUSE hair loss for some
high_ph_issue.root_causes: Hair loss caused by myriad issues, beginning with diet

shampoo_bar_warnings.recommendation: Steer clear of medicinal ingredient claims unless making syndet bars

honest_approach.research_resource: Chemist's Corner - for veracity and hype in ingredient claims
honest_approach.reputable_companies: Don't use or tone down marketing hype

key_takeaways.1: Saponification destroys most beneficial properties of ingredients
key_takeaways.2: Rinse-off products have minimal contact time anyway
key_takeaways.3: Medical claims for soap are illegal without FDA approval
key_takeaways.4: HP soap with post-cook additions can preserve some ingredients
key_takeaways.6: Use extracts for fun, color, scent - not medical claims
key_takeaways.7: Hair regrowth claims from any plant extract are false

quiz_questions.a: Not much - not enough to honestly claim medicinal benefits
quiz_questions.explanation: Plus rinse-off products have minimal contact time anyway

quiz_questions.q: Does adding ingredients at trace preserve their properties?
quiz_questions.a: No - soap is still undergoing saponification at trace
quiz_questions.explanation: Need to add AFTER saponification is complete (HP method)

quiz_questions.q: How can you preserve ingredient properties in Hot Process soap?
quiz_questions.a: Add oils/ingredients AFTER the cook is complete, when saponification is finished
quiz_questions.explanation: Can use 0% superfat in calculator, then add superfat oils at end

quiz_questions.q: What are syndet bars and why do they preserve ingredients?
quiz_questions.a: Synthetic detergent bars - not soap, so no saponification occurs
quiz_questions.explanation: Not all shampoo bars are soap - syndet bars keep ingredients intact

quiz_questions.q: Are hair regrowth claims from blueberry extract or herbs legitimate?
quiz_questions.a: No - dishonest marketing with no scientific evidence
quiz_questions.explanation: Such claims would require expensive FDA testing and approval

Syndet Scholar: Understand soap vs syndet distinction

van_kush_connection.philosophy: Honesty in claims - use salves/balms for medicinal herbs, not rinse-off soap
